triage_guidelines:
There are three categories of relevant papers:

Gene expression signature
The paper is likely to contain a gene expression signature.
Other high-priority signature
The paper is likely to contain an immune signature related to another high-priority data type. These include proteins/cytokine, metabolites and cell type signatures.
Low-priority signature
The paper is likely to contain an immune signature related to low-priority data type. This covers all other response components (for example, clinical measurements, antibodies, etc.). Note that studies that do not profile the in vivo response (ie, a direct measurement of gene expression or expression change from a tissue) should also be considered low priority. This would include, for example, studies that sample a tissue and then stimulate/treat in vitro and report on these responses as signatures.
Other criteria for being included as relevant (one of the first three categories above):
  • Human
  • Any age
  • SARS-Cov-2 infection and/or COVID-19 disease
There are two categories of not-relevant papers:
Review article
The paper is a review article (not relevant).
Not relevant
Any other paper (not relevant).
Showing up to 10 randomly selected papers. Refresh to see more.

solicit_message_template:
Dear {{contributor}},

I am writing on behalf of the COVID-19 Signatures team of the NIH/NIAID Human Immunology Project Consortium (HIPC; https://immuneprofiling.org).  As part of our efforts to help address the ongoing pandemic, we are creating a public resource of immune signatures related to COVID-19. In particular, we would like to include

{{paper}}

in the initial database release. To help our curators enter it correctly, we would greatly appreciate if you or one of your collaborators could help by filling out the brief form at http://covid-signatures.org/entry/{{id}} to make sure we get all the tissues, cohorts, etc. We expect it would only take a few minutes for your team, but it will greatly improve the quality of our listing.

Once you submit your signature, our team will leverage this information to manually curate your paper and extract additional details to make the research results available to the wider scientific community in a machine-readable, fully searchable format. This will increase the utility (and visibility) of your work in the effort to understand COVID-19.

If you have any questions or comments, please do not hesitate to reach out by replying to this email.

Thank you in advance for your help,

Robert McDougal, Health Informatics Division, Dept of Biostatistics, Yale School of Public Health

CC: Steven Kleinstein, Dept of Pathology, Dept of Immunobiology, Yale School of Medicine

userentry.title: Immune Signature Submission
userentry.header:
As part of our efforts to help address the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the NIH/NIAID Human Immunology Project Consortium (HIPC) and the Immunophenotyping Assessment in a COVID-19 Cohort (IMPACC) network are creating a resource of immune signatures related to the host response to SARS-CoV-2 infection. "Signatures" describe alterations in the levels of one or more response components (i.e., biological entities such as genes or cell types) that result from a particular comparison in the context of an immune exposure. An example immune signature is provided in the light grey background text in each box of the form below.

We have identified the paper listed below as highly relevant for this effort. We appreciate your help in filling out the fields below in order to help us identify the human immune signature(s) in your paper. Note that many papers report multiple signatures, each associated with a distinct comparison. These should be provided separately by clicking on the "Add another signature" button at the end of the form.

If you have any questions, please reply to the original email request. Placeholder text in light gray give example values; these will disappear when you start entering data.

global_fields.name: Paper
global_fields.help_text: Citation to the paper whose data is entered below, in any format
global_fields.example: Smith et al. (2020) Immune signatures of Covid-19. J Important Science.

global_fields.name: Contributor
global_fields.help_text: Name of the person who contributed the signature.

fields.name: Brief description
fields.help_text: Describe in one sentence the essence of the signature.
fields.example: Genes up-regulated in PBMCs of young adults at 1 day after hospital admission when comparing severe vs. mild disease in COVID-19.

fields.name: Exact source
fields.help_text: Description of the exact source of the signature in the paper; include link to figure/table if available.

fields.name: Tissue
fields.help_text: Tissue where the signature is derived from; for cell names, please use the cell ontology (https://ontology.immport.org)

fields.name: Immune exposure
fields.help_text: Immune exposure that produced the signature.

fields.name: Cohort
fields.help_text: Description of the cohort that was profiled to produce the signature

fields.name: Comparison
fields.help_text: Comparison that was carried out to produce the signature.
fields.example: severe vs mild infection at 1-day post-hospital admission

fields.name: Repository ID
fields.help_text: ID of dataset in a data repository (GEO, ArrayExpress, FlowRepository, or a link) if applicable and available.

fields.name: Platform
fields.help_text: Type of identifiers for original members of the signature as included in the RESPONSE_COMPONENTS Field (eg, HG-U133A_2 for the HG-133A_2 microarray, Ensembl_Gene_IDs for genes from an Ensembl Transcriptiome, Cell Ontology for cell types).

fields.name: Response Components
fields.help_text: Comma delimited list of identifiers (e.g., genes, proteins, metabolites, cell types) - exactly as they appeared in the source publication. This should be with as little transformation as possible (i.e. if both Ensembl gene IDs and Gene Symbols are available for a sequencing study, give Ensembl Gene IDs).

fields.name: Response Behavior
fields.help_text: Behavior of the Response Components with respect to the Comparison carried out. Separate signatures should be submitted to describe response components with different behaviors (eg, up and down).
